text: - [Instructor] In this video,

you'll see how to
synchronize AWS Config data
into the ServiceNow CMDB.

With the AWS Service Management
Connector for ServiceNow,

you can manage AWS
resources from ServiceNow,
have near real-time visibility
of AWS resources to ServiceNow users,
and facilitate IT service management.
We'll begin an AWS Config,
which we can see is enabled

within the Ohio region
of this AWS account.
We can discover AWS resources managed
by AWS Config in ServiceNow

by implementing the AWS
Service Management Connector.
Let's go to ServiceNow and take a look.
This account is already configured
with the AWS Service Management Connector.
Let's go to our AWS accounts

to view the AWS Config
integration settings.
These are the required configurations.

Notice that we have selected
Integrate with AWS Config.
This setting allows us
to seamlessly synchronize AWS Config data
into the ServiceNow CMDB.
We have also associated this integration
with the region of our AWS account.
Next, we'll run a synchronization
to bring AWS Config data into ServiceNow.

Let's navigate to our
list of scheduled jobs.

The connector installed
a list of scheduled jobs
for various integrations.
We'll search for AWS Config.

This job is scheduled
to run every 31 minutes.
We'll execute it now.
The API calls from ServiceNow
to AWS Config populate the CMDB

with data according to
class or resource type.
These are the resource

types that the AWS Config
integration supports.
Returning to AWS Config for a moment,
we can see four identified resource types:

Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud,
or Amazon EC2 instance,
subnet and VPC,

and Amazon Simple Storage
Service, or Amazon S3 bucket.

Let's check if our
Amazon EC2 instance data
is available in ServiceNow.
Here are the EC2 instances.

Let's drill down into the
first one to see the metadata.
Here's the metadata and related items.
We can also change the filter level

to see more immediate relationships
for this EC2 metadata.
For our purposes,

let's change the maximum
level from 3 to 1.
We can also see what upstream

and downstream relationships
this EC2 instance has.

Here's the full map reflecting
the relationship level
we just specified.
Next, let's go back

and review the other
resource types we integrated.
Let's see how many VPCs were identified.
There is one VPC here.
Let's find it in the AWS Config console.
Here it is.

Let's go back to ServiceNow
and drill down into it.
As with the EC2 instances,

we can see the immediate
relationships associated
with this VPC.
Next, let's find the Amazon S3 buckets.
Here they are. Let's drill down.
Here we can see the AWS Config data
and if it is compliant or non-compliant.

The AWS online documentation
provides more information
about the current integration features
and supported resource types.

You've just seen how to
synchronize AWS Config data
into the ServiceNow CMDB.

You can learn more about
this topic in the description
and links for this video.

Thanks for watching. Now
it's your turn to try.
